text.p: Summit Design Inc shares rose over 20 percent on their first day of trading, up 2-1/2 to 12 after their initial public offering on Friday.
The graphic design firm sold four million shares, which priced at $9.50 each, above their estimated price range of $7 to $9 each.
Other companies that made their IPO market debuts:

-- Spatial Technology Inc was one of the most heavily traded stocks on the American Stock Exchange at its market debut. The shares edged up 1/4 to 5 after terms of the IPO were cut to about $15 million from $21 million.
The Boulder, Colorado company develops three dimensional modeling software.
Its planned IPO of 2.1 million shares to price at $9 to $11 was scrapped earlier this week due to market conditions, according to lead underwriter Dain Bosworth.
But comanager Cruttendon Roth Inc took Spatial public, offering three million shares for $5 each.

-- Matrix Capital Corp shares rose 15 percent, up 1-1/2 to 11-1/2 from their IPO price of $10. The company offered 1.75 million shares, up from its original plan of 1.5 million shares in a range of $9 to $11.
Piper Jaffray Inc was the lead underwriter of the offering. Matrix is a specialized financial services company.

-- Specialty Catalog Corp shares rose 1/16 to 6-9/16 from their IPO price of $6.50 a share. The company, a direct marketer targeting niche consumer product categories, offered 1.25 million shares which priced below their price talk of $7.25 to $8 a share.
GKN was the lead underwriter of the offering.
-- Viatel Inc shares were flat at $12 at their market debut. The company offered 8,667,000 shares for $12 each, the bottom of their estimated range of $12 to $15.

Viatel offers long distance phone service in western Europe, Latin America, the United States and the Pacific Rim. It plans to use proceeds from the offering for a network upgrade and expansion, and investment in undersea fiber optic cable.
